item.title: Wiki Documentation
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This article is a reference on keeping the wiki running and making changes to it.

General

We use Wordpress for the wiki backend, so for general information and answers, check out either the Wordpress Codex or the Wordpress Development Stack Exchange.

Backend

Theme files (all relative to wp-themes/wikiwp-child):
  • js/wiki.js
    • Front-end script.
    • Any front-end dynamic behavior you want to see should be written in here.
  • js/scripts.js
    • Compilation of third party js scripts we use.
  • images
    • Images (duh).
  • content-%TYPE%.php, single-%TYPE%.php
    • Contain templates for post types
    • Usually, the former contains the contents of the Wordpress loop, the latter does not. The Wordpress codex has more details about the difference.
      • In general we've stuck with the convention. Lazy, late night programming might have caused some inconsistencies though.
    • "bug-library-bugs" is the slug of the issue post type (this was the default)
    • content.php and single.php are the default templates that are used for articles and post types for which we don't have a specific template.
  • screenshot.png
    • Image used in the Appearance » Themes pageю
  • styles.less, styles.css
    • Wiki appearance code is held in styles.css.
    • There're also base styles in the parente theme folder's styles.css.
    • Since CSS is annoying, all styles are written in LESS, then compiled into CSS. To make style changes, I recommend you download Koala, make changes to the .less file, use Koala to compile a .css file, then upload the .css file to the server.
      • This is a little more involved then changing the .css file directly, but is much easier to maintain in the long run.
      • If you do decide to modify the .css file, then delete the .less file so there's no confusion in the future about which has the most up-to-date styles.
  • functions.php
    • The core file containing our changes.
    • This file is an amalgamation of our changes and snippets from other people. I've commented it fairly liberally.
    • Changes to the admin screen and to the wiki read view are made here. This isn't a good practice. Admin changes should be kept elsewhere (functions.php should be reserved for theme-specific changes), but c'est la vie.

Adding Plugins

To keep things documented, I've tried noting plugin source code changes on Updating Wiki and Plugin Versions. If you make any changes, I'd recommend doing so as well.

Adding Post Types

A few steps here:
  • Use the CPT UI plugin to add the custom post type to the database (or manually edit the functions.php file)
  • Add content-%post_type%.php and single-%post_type%.php to the file hierarchy (modify as you see fit).
Any other changes depend on what the custom post type does. Have a look at how to add custom post types to Wordpress for more details. Mostly you'll be looking at:
  • The Advanced Custom Fields plugin for adding unique edit options.
  • functions.php and the content template for fine-tuning functionality.

Users

Adding

Since we're relying on Apache authentication, adding users takes a bit longer for us. Follow these steps:
  1. Add a user to Apache and the SVN.
  2. Wiki admin screen » Users » Add New
  3. Enter the same username as in Apache. The remaining credentials are arbitrary. Notably, the password field is not used (enter anything).
  4. Set the Role to one of the 3 shown below depending on what the user will do with the wiki.

Roles

Mostly we follow Wordpress's default roles. Guidelines when assigning roles:
  • Administrator - Can see and do everything that can be done on the wiki
  • Author - Can read and write posts, sees a simplified interface
  • Subscriber - Can only read posts, can't access wiki admin screen

MATLAB

The wiki interfaces with MATLAB using the static matlab_wiki class. Usage notes can be found in the actual file and at Writing on the Wiki. We make use of a special user - matlabber -  for the actual upload. Credentials can be found in matlab_wiki.m.

item.title: Using LaTeX
item.dc:creator: admin
item.excerpt:encoded: Instructions and nuances regarding the use of LaTeX on the wiki

item.title: Updating Wiki and Plugin Versions
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
This page contains info on updating wiki and plugin versions. In general, most things are safe to update. However, due to dependencies updating some things might cause others to stop working, so be ready to revert and debug. There are a few cases where we've extended a plugin's source, so updating would overwrite our extension. These and other nuances are listed below.

Wordpress

Safe to update. We made no core file changes. Note that some plugins might stop working, so be ready to revert if needed.

WikiWP Theme

Updating

Safe to update. We extend the WikiWP theme using our own WikiWP-child theme (more on child themes). This allows us to update the base WikiWP theme without overwriting our changes. That said, doing so might break some of our functions that depend on the theme running a particular way, but we can revert if needed.

Changing

If changing to a different theme, make sure to test the MATLAB-wiki interface. Namely, copy over any MATLAB-related code in functions.php (on the wiki side) and confirm that matlab_wiki.m is functional with the new theme.

Plugins

Where plugin files were modified, be careful when updating. Our changes will be overwritten. In this case do a diff between the updated file and the old one to transfer the changes. Some notes about updating specific plugins:

Bug Library

  • bug-library.php - Made extensive changes.
  • stylesheet.css - Copied contents to theme stylesheet (when the plugin loaded this file, it made some server-stalling cURL requests; still unsure of why this happened, but just removing the function call to load this file solved it).

Advanced Custom Fields (ACF)

  • No plugin files were modified.
  • matlab_wiki.m relies on a certain storage structure for the tables made by ACF. After updating, confirm that we can still upload and download sensors.

Duplicate Title Validation

  • duptitles.js and duplicate-title-validate.php - Made minor changes.

Table of Contents Plus

  • toc.php - Made minor changes.

Taxonomy Font Icons

  • taxonomy-font-icons-class.php - Changed line 98: "http" » "https".
  • taxonomy-font-icons-functions.php - Made minor changes.

TinyMCE Visual Editor Comment

  • setting.php - Changed line 6: "'https://www.bengalpix.com/images/icons/addcomment.gif'" » "null"
item.excerpt:encoded: Nuances about updating Wordpress, the WikiWP theme, and plugins

item.title: Writing on the Wiki
item.dc:creator: admin
item.content:encoded:
Posts

There are different types of 'posts' you can make on the wiki:
  • Articles - Standard wiki post. Most things you post would be these.
  • Pages - Static wiki posts. These are used for things that are static, but could have dynamic content. Best to edit, but not make new ones.
  • Issues - On-going projects or bugs.
  • Papers - Summary posts for journal/conference papers. Can link these to related articles.
  • Updates - Template posts for writing weekly progress updates.
To make a new post, hover over 'New' in the header bar (top of the page), or go to the wiki dashboard (click on 'Wiki' in header bar or your name in the sidebar). To edit an existing post, either:
  1. Navigate to that post and hit 'Edit' in the header bar. Some posts have other edit links visible.
  2. Go to the wiki dashboard, select the post type in the side bar, then click on the post name.

Writing Articles

Adding Media/Attachments

Couple of ways:
  1. Drag-and-drop files directly onto the post. This places images where your cursor is and creates text-links to other file attachments.
  2. Click "Add Media" and navigate the interface there.
  3. Use the 'Attachments' box below the post editor. This places attachments in a list at the bottom of the post.
  4. Use matlab_wiki.upload_image() or matlab_wiki.upload_file(). This also places attachments in the 'Attachments' box for the post.

Excerpts

Recommend you fill out a post summary in the 'Excerpts' box below the post editor. Posts with excerpts display their excerpts on category pages.

Tables of Contents

Tables of contents are automatically added for articles and issues that have 3 or more headings.

Formatting

Basics

Most things are pretty self-evident. Recommend you learn the shortcuts for various formatting options. Note that the toolbar has 2 levels. Click the toolbar toggle icon to display it.

Code

To create marked up code blocks, surround your code with [programming_language] ... [/programming_language], using the actual programming language you're writing. Most popular languages are supported (notably 'C' and 'MATLAB'). E.g. [c] #include <stdio.h> long int multiplyNumbers(int n); int main() { int n; printf("Enter a positive integer: "); scanf("%d", &n); printf("Factorial of %d = %ld", n, multiplyNumbers(n)); return 0; } long int multiplyNumbers(int n) { if (n >= 1) return n * multiplyNumbers(n-1); else return 1; } [/c]

Images

Click on an image to display alignment options. Click the pencil icon on the image to custom size it or add a caption. E.g. [caption id="" align="aligncenter" width="560"] Sample captioned image[/caption]

Copying+Pasting Text

In general, use ctrl+shift+v instead of ctrl+v when pasting code into the editor, especially when copying from the web. This is because Wordpress takes the native, underlying HTML when it does a regular paste. But when using ctrl+shift+v, you remove all formatting and copy over the plain text. Often times it won't cause a problem, but this can prevent some headaches.

Article Link (Permalink)

After saving (or after some time passes on the edit screen) a permalink will be generated for your article (shown under the article title on the edit screen). If you started the body of the article before the title, then the permalink might just be some numeric ID. Hit 'Edit' to change it. To get an automatically generated one based on your title, hit 'Edit', delete the existing permalink, and hit 'OK'.

LaTeX

See 'Using LaTeX'.

Revisions

Wordpress has a built-in version control system (VCS). Every time you save a post, a revision gets saved. These can be seen in the bottom of the post edit screen under revisions (only visible once there are 2+ revisions). Clicking on the date beside a revision allows you to see the changes made and to revert back to that revision if needed.

Parents and Children

You can select articles to be parents or children of other articles. This is good if you'd like to designate an article to be a summary (parent), then have links to more detailed individual articles (children). Parents and children show up in lists at the bottom of each article.

Writing Other Post Types

Mostly the same as articles. Mostly these are just articles with some nuances.

Issues

  • Have additional 'Issue Details' dropdowns to select.
  • All issues appear on the Issue Tracker page.

Pages

  • Pages should be made for static content that we want to have always visible and accessible.
  • In general, don't make these. An article is probably more appropriate.

Papers

  • Have additional "About the Paper" fields.
  • Can specify related articles to the paper.
  • After writing a paper post, the paper will automatically appear in the "Current Papers" table on the 'Papers' page.
  • If its target date is near enough, the paper post will automatically appear in the "Upcoming Events" table on the Home page.

Updates

  • Titles and links are automatically generated and are immutable. This keeps them all following the same format.
  • If you write one update, it is autotitled "Week of %START_OF_WEEK%". If you write a second one in the same week, it is autotitled "Week of %START_OF_NEXT_WEEK%".
  • Only one author per update (you're auto-selected).
  • These can be sorted by author on the Updates page.
item.excerpt:encoded: Tips about writing articles on the wiki.
